awd_titl_txt: Towards a Complete Understanding of Stellar Feedback in Massive Star Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
Anna Rosen is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the University of California, San Diego.  Rosen will perform numerical simulations of how stellar feedback – the energy and momentum injected into the interstellar medium – from radiation, stellar winds, outflows, and cosmic rays affects the formation of massive stars and star clusters.  Results from the study will allow astronomers to better understand the role of feedback in the processes of star formation and galaxy formation.  Alongside this research, Rosen will conduct education and outreach activities centered around non-traditional and underrepresented community college students, providing research mentoring and professional development for incoming students at the University, and developing videos introducing computational astrophysics and scientific computing to community college students.

Rosen will explore how various feedback mechanisms limit massive star formation on both the individual and cluster scales by performing a suite of radiation-magnetohydrodynamic simulations that follow the formation of individual massive stars within massive star clusters.  Using these simulations, she will determine the initial conditions required for massive star formation and the properties of the resulting HII regions.  Additionally, by including realistic dust physics and anisotropic cosmic ray diffusion into a new modeling framework, she will assess how stellar feedback limits stellar masses, controls star formation rates in molecular clouds, and potentially ejects gas over large scales.  Her results will lead to better feedback models that will be used in future cosmological simulations and aid multi-wavelength observations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for NSF Award 2202249

Exploring How Stellar Feedback Influences the Birth of Massive Stars and Star Clusters

This project studied how young massive stars and star clusters form, focusing on the role that stellar feedback (stellar winds, radiation, and collimated protostellar outflows) from young stars plays in shaping their mass growth and shaping the interstellar medium. We used high-resolution 3D simulations to examine feedback effects both in isolated pre-stellar cores and in star-forming regions within giant molecular clouds (GMCs).

Intellectual Merit

We found that when massive protostars reach about 30 times the Sun’s mass and begin contracting toward the main sequence, stellar winds can inhibit further accretion, demonstrating that stellar wind feedback may set a natural upper mass limit for stars forming in isolated environments. By comparing our simulations to X-ray observations of compact HII regions, we showed that detecting soft X-rays (0.5–3 keV) from deeply embedded protostars is difficult due to strong absorption by surrounding gas and dust, in agreement with past observations.

Our work highlights the importance of including stellar wind feedback in models of massive star and massive star cluster formation. It also helps interpret telescope observations across multiple wavelengths, especially in dense, feedback-dominated environments.

Broader Impacts

This award supported the mentoring of three Ohio State University undergraduate and graduate students and one Rutgers graduate student. We collaborated on projects using numerical simulations and data from the Chandra and Fermi observatories to study feedback from massive star clusters, helping train future researchers in computational and observational astrophysics.

Our results were published in:

  • Rosen (2022): Feedback-regulated formation of massive stars.
  • Guszejnov et al. (2022a, 2022b, 2023): Star formation and IMF variations in GMCs.
  • Grudić et al. (2022), Hopkins et al. (2022): Multi-feedback simulations of star cluster formation.
  • Limbach et al. (2023): The TEMPO Survey for transiting objects in Orion.
  • Appel (2023): Star cluster formation with individually resolved feedback.

These results were presented at conferences, seminars, and colloquia.

Conclusion

This work improved our understanding of how stellar feedback regulates the formation of massive stars and clusters and provided hands-on training opportunities for early-career scientists.


Last Modified: 04/03/2025
Modified by: Anna L Rosen

Project Outcomes Report for NSF Award 2202249


Exploring How Stellar Feedback Influences the Birth of Massive Stars and Star Clusters


This project studied how young massive stars and star clusters form, focusing on the role that stellar feedback (stellar winds, radiation, and collimated protostellar outflows) from young stars plays in shaping their mass growth and shaping the interstellar medium. We used high-resolution 3D simulations to examine feedback effects both in isolated pre-stellar cores and in star-forming regions within giant molecular clouds (GMCs).


Intellectual Merit


We found that when massive protostars reach about 30 times the Suns mass and begin contracting toward the main sequence, stellar winds can inhibit further accretion, demonstrating that stellar wind feedback may set a natural upper mass limit for stars forming in isolated environments. By comparing our simulations to X-ray observations of compact HII regions, we showed that detecting soft X-rays (0.53 keV) from deeply embedded protostars is difficult due to strong absorption by surrounding gas and dust, in agreement with past observations.


Our work highlights the importance of including stellar wind feedback in models of massive star and massive star cluster formation. It also helps interpret telescope observations across multiple wavelengths, especially in dense, feedback-dominated environments.


Broader Impacts


This award supported the mentoring of three Ohio State University undergraduate and graduate students and one Rutgers graduate student. We collaborated on projects using numerical simulations and data from the Chandra and Fermi observatories to study feedback from massive star clusters, helping train future researchers in computational and observational astrophysics.


Our results were published in:

Rosen (2022): Feedback-regulated formation of massive stars.
Guszejnov et al. (2022a, 2022b, 2023): Star formation and IMF variations in GMCs.
Grudić et al. (2022), Hopkins et al. (2022): Multi-feedback simulations of star cluster formation.
Limbach et al. (2023): The TEMPO Survey for transiting objects in Orion.
Appel (2023): Star cluster formation with individually resolved feedback.



These results were presented at conferences, seminars, and colloquia.


Conclusion


This work improved our understanding of how stellar feedback regulates the formation of massive stars and clusters and provided hands-on training opportunities for early-career scientists.					Last Modified: 04/03/2025
